Compilation is a 'lossy' process in the sense that it's often not 100%
reversible... So in that sense, information certainly got lost.

But a correct compiler will preserve sufficient information that
process-execution complies with what the source code specifies.


Now about the Java bytecodes; I never looked at them. But I do know that
there's a 'constant pool' for every class which contains all the string
constants referenced somehow in that class; either thru method-invocation or
direct string refs. Method-calling should use the values from this same
constant-pool; the method-invocation itself contains a reference to this
entry in the constant-pool.

So 10 invocations of the same method in the same class don't cause the
entire method-name to be included in the constant-pool for every invocation.
If the same string-constant *does* appear multiple times in a classes'
constant pool that can be said to be a compiler bug - after all, string are
immutable.

About parsing the string to find out the actual bytecode to invoke on a
method invocation - I have no idea how that is done.

How does a C++ compiler/linker actually store the names of the methods that
it needs to call? Doesn't it also have to store a lot of information about
the namespaces, method names, overloads, parameter types, etc? To determine
dynamically at runtime / dll-loadtime where in the code the CPU needs to
jump for a virtual method invocation? Where does it store that info, and
when/where/how is that resolved to a memory-address?

Is Java-bytecode really hugely inefficient compared to how C++ solves the
problem?


regards,

--Tim

-----Original Message-----
From: Ron Jeffries [mailto:ronjeffries@...]
Sent: dinsdag 30 september 2003 19:44
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] Re: Help plz...


On Tuesday, September 30, 2003, at 12:07:31 PM, Jim Dixon wrote:

>> > I know that this is official Sun doctrine.  But compilation is always
>> > a lossy process, and the smaller the target instruction set, the more
>> > information you lose.  The JVM has a small instruction set.  To
increment
>> > a variable, you put a 1 on the stack and say "add".  Oh my :-(
>>
>> Why does that trouble you?

> Is this a real question??

Yes.

> It's just an example.  With a larger instruction set, you can increment
> variables in place, at a lower cost in terms of code size and run time.

> The main point is that compilation is a lossy process.  When you write
> i++ it's succinct but very clear.  The compiler translates this into
>   push variable
>   push 1
>   add
>   store variable
> While it's not impossible, it's difficult and expensive for a bytecode
> (re)compiler to sort out what's going on here and optimize back to the
> succintness of the original.  The larger the instruction set, the more
> information preserved in the bytecode, the less difficult and expensive
> the process is.

On the contrary, when it comes to the execution of the program, compilation
is emphatically not a lossy process. If it were, then the program's
behavior would not be what we expect. If it is what we expect, then no
information has been lost.

Ron Jeffries
www.XProgramming.com
Get over it.  -- The Eagles
